citation.span: International Standard Archival Authority Record For Corporate Bodies, Persons and Families

descriptiveNote.p: [Eachan MacIsaig; Eachann mac Ruaraidh/ Eachann MacIosaig, Eachann mac Ruaraidh]; joiner, Iochdar, South Uist

biogHist.p: Hector MacIsaac, wright, was born c1797 in the district of Iochdar, South Uist, the son of Roderick and Ann née Macintyre. MacIsaac lived on the present-day croft of 4 Ardmore, Iochdar, but probably travelled around the island as a carpenter, the cottar smallholding he possessed in his native district being an auxiliary to his main trade. Although Alexander Carmichael makes much of the poverty and isolation Hector MacIsaac suffered in his old age when he knew him, MacIsaac had travelled much in his younger days and had taught himself English. Among the notes John Francis Campbell made when he visited the storyteller on 30 September 1871, he quotes (and translates) a conversation between the two: Age and poverty and all evils or [are] on my back my memory is gone but I have travelled Scotland and I have never seen the man to beat me. I have learned English. I was out selling eggs. I was a carpenter &c. – give him a bit backy. I gave him half a mutchkin 1/0 another two glasses in all 6 glasses of whisky. [NLS Adv. MS 50.2.4 fo.226] While engaged in collecting for John Francis Campbell’s Popular Tales of the West Highlands project, Hector Maclean certainly visited MacIsaac in 1859, referring to him in his list of Uist and Barra storytellers as: Hector MacIsaac, wright, Iochdar, recited several legends for me and some tales about the Fînn. His stories are principally dialogue. [NLS Adv. MS 50.1.7 fo.33]

It is interesting to note, and rather puzzling too, that there are no stories ascribed to MacIsaac in Campbell’s collections, either printed or in manuscript. Alexander Carmichael, on the other hand, clearly enjoyed a particular rapport with Hector MacIsaac. He recorded a Fenian lay, ‘Moladh Ghoill’, from the seanchaidh on 21 July 1865 [CW103 f.10v], and probably at least made notes on another poem, ‘Comhairle Fhinn air Oscar’ [ibid. fo.10].On 6 October 1865 Carmichael returned to MacIsaac, recording from him two Fenian laysCW105/9.

The following year, on 24 April, Carmichael returned and recorded the story ‘Carmag mac Art mhic Cuinn Cheud-chathaich’, one of MacIsaac’s favourites. The notes he appended to the tale offer us a precious insight into the character of the seanchaidh, how he had acquired his stories, and indeed into the wider storytelling culture in the islands at the time: Hector MacIosag despises mythological tales and says they are great rubbish in which I fear many men of greater pretention [sic] will concur. But of the Fingalians tales he declares them to be worthy [of] the attention of princes – that they are the most elegant excellent and delightful tales that man could listen to. He says that he heard tales read as repeated by persons whom he knows and that the tales were so garbled and mangled that he hung down his head and closed his ears for very shame. He declares that When [he] is done planting his potatoes he will travel over the F[ord]– a dis[tance] of about 21 m[iles] – to give me a proper opp[ortunity] of taking down any word he has before he dies. He says he he [sic] neither son nor dau[ghter] except one little girl to whom he can leave his legacy of prose and poetry. And as he likes me better than any other person in the world he is desirous I should become poss. of this invaluable legacy. Ind[eed?] he considers it an imper[tinence] that his young daug[hter] does not exhibit a wish to become poss[essor] of these tales of the Feine in prose and poetry. He dec[lares] that there is no man from the Butt of Lewis to Barra Head – 200 m. – who has the history of the Fing[alians] so well as he. Re[citers] are the most egotistical set I have ever met. Each thinks himself much better than his neigh. in reciting. Each declares that other re[citers] are only garbling the tales. Ruarai Ruadh from whom E[achann] MacIosaig learnt his tales died about 40 y[ears] ago – about 80 years of age. A gentleman came from Edin[burgh] to take down from him. He remained several weeks from writing from his dictation. For excelling so much in this Lord MacDon[ald] generously gave him a house and piece of land free of rent and this he enjoyed while he lived. Proba[bly] he was the last ?lsa? reciter who enjoyed free lands for his an[cient] lore. He was a catechist and used to go about catechising but in the reality his audiences were more partial to his old lore than to better talk. And truth to say we believe the old man took more delight in reciting and expounding the Fing[alian] tales and poems than those of the Bible. CW104/28

The high estimation in which Alexander Carmichael held Hector MacIsaac is demonstrated by the fact that he was John Francis Campbell’s main informant on his Ossianic folklore tour, arranged by Carmichael, in autumn 1871. Although Carmichael, at that time living in Iochdar, accompanied Campbell on at least one visit to MacIsaac, this goes unmentioned in Campbell’s rough personal journal of the occasion. In compiling and writing up the story of ‘Carmag mac Airt’ – the same tale which had been recorded by Carmichael five years previouly – Campbell’s chief source (after the version in Popular Tales ii!) was: Eachan Mac Cisaig, a pauper in receipt of three shillings a month living in the Island of South Uist Sept 30, 1871. This man is full of Fenian stuff He says that he learned it chiefly from one Ruadhri Ruagh a catechist who used to go about in the beginning of this century reciting to audiences whom he first drew and then instructed in religious knowledge. [NLS Adv. MS 50.2.4 fo.111] Campbell notes that ‘it cost me five hours’, from 10.30am to 3.30pm, to write the story over 17 pages: ‘my reciter never flagged or got bothered’ [ibid.; also fos.115–27, 202–18: but note fo.198 where Campbell records that he began at 11.15am, after a nine miles’ walk, with questions concerning Fenian miscellanea]. ‘I am Eachan MacCiosaig no man can tell you as I can.’ [ibid. 182] MacIsaac clearly enjoyed telling the tale of Carmag: I always like that story I am now pleased that I see that you have it written. I liked that story better than any other. It is a great story. I learned it from Ruraraidh [sic] Ruagh the man who gave me seanachas na fian. My Father was page to the father of Mac Mhic Ailean & his grandfather and all, but not his page. Oh Righ, deep sigh. [ibid. fo.218]

Campbell records his own opinions on MacIsaac’s style, echoing those of Hector Maclean: This is a very long winded version of a story in my book but as the old boy will not take crossexamination obliged to take what I can get. [ibid. fo.201v] 10½ to 3½ 5 hours of rigmarole all excellent language and but little repetition but full of conversations which do not help on the incidents though they spin out the play. [ibid. fo.218]

Campbell returned to Hector MacIsaac three days later, on 2 October 1871, and recorded ‘Comhairle Fhinn’ and ‘Moladh Ghoill’, both taken down by Carmichael previously. MacIsaac stressed that the Gaelic versions of Macpherson’s ‘Ossian’ ‘do not please me at all’ [ibid. fo.230]. Although most of his Ossianic store was learnt verbatim from the catechist Roderick MacQueen, Ruaraidh Ruadh MacCuithein, MacIsaac also makes a tantalising reference to material learnt from his father (Mac Mhic Ailein’s father’s page) which ‘was in the book Fear o Gharibh thir – There was much about Eirinn, Clann Mhurrich had 7 cart loads’ [ibid. fo.197; cf. Alan Bruford, ‘A lost MacMhuirich manuscript’, Scottish Gaelic Studies, 10 (1965), 158–61]. On 4 April 1872 Carmichael, then still living in the district, recorded antiquarian material from Hector MacIsaac, Ceann Langabhat, Iochdar: information about the MacMhuirichs in Staoidhligearraidh, Caisteal Bhuirgh, Caisteal Bheagram, and the Clan Ranalds themselves[CW MS 119 fos.61v–?68v]. On the same day, though in a different notebook or on paper (we only have a transcription) he recorded an outline of the legend of the Children of Lìr who wer turned into swans for three hundred years [CW 7 fos.17v–18]. On the following day, in another notebook, Carmichael took down from MacIsaac genealogical lore and a couple of supernatural tales. These mostly relate to the remote east side of the island, the MacIsaac kindred being notoriously immune to the attack of evil spirits haunting Glen Liadail there CW90/41-52.

Perhaps the most interesting item Carmichael recorded from Hector MacIsaac is, at least in its manuscript version, the most problematic regarding its ascription and dating. Carmichael had already collected a version of Tòireachd na Táine or Táin Bó Cuailgne from Patrick Morrison, Baile a’ Mhanaich, Benbecula, over 17–18 April 1866 CW482; see CW104/19; CW154/2. On 15 August 1872 he recorded another telling of the tale from Hector MacIsaac, but ascribed to the wrong reciter, and on the wrong date as well.

The reason why seems to be a stray stanza Carmichael had noted down from Hector MacLeod, the blind shoemaker from Iochdar apparently related to MacIsaac, on 29 September 1871 CW482 f.31. Judging from the position of the original verse, scribbled in pencil at the end of a neat transcription in ink of Patrick Morrison’s version of the Tàin, what happened seems to have been that Carmichael recited Morrison’s Tàin to Hector MacLeod, in the hope of gleaning some additions or corrections to the tale. In the event, he received nothing more for his pains than a few lines of obscure poetry which the reciter himself didn’t fully understand.

Carmichael later transcribed into a field notebook, in ink, the obscure verse he had scribbled down from Hector MacLeod CW105/12. It might be suspected that he did so in order to recite it to the shoemaker’s relation Hector MacIsaac as a prompt to see if he could throw any light on its meaning or provenance. Doubtless he also told MacIsaac of the circumstances of the original recording. The seanchaidh promptly went on to recite a full, and different, version of the Tàin itself.

Nevertheless, in the heading to the recording Carmichael misascribed the reciter as Hector MacLeod, the reciter of the stanza who was by that time certainly dead, although he did preserve Hector MacIsaac’s patronymic, Eachann mac Ruairidh CW105/14. Not only did he get the name of the reciter wrong, but the date too: 15 August 1873. We know that this is impossible because Carmichael’s transcription of MacIsaac’s tale was read out to the Gaelic Society of Inverness in November 1872. What happened? It looks as if when Carmichael transcribed Hector MacLeod’s stanza into his field notebook, he mistakenly dated the recording of the stray stanza to 1872. When he headed the next item – MacIsaac’s Tàin – he realised that the stanza had in fact been jotted down the previous year. If that year was 1872, then that meant that this year was 1873.

The version of the Tàin as printed in the Transactions of the Gaelic Society of Inverness, ii, is rightly ascribed, to Eachann Mac-iosaig, Ceannlangabhat. Carmichael states that the reciter: is a descendant of, and is called after, Hector Macleod, the Uist bard … who rendered good service to many who were out in the ’45. [p. 39] This is indeed possible, but it may be again that the writer confused the two Hectors, and that it was Hector MacLeod the shoemaker who was a descendant of ‘the “mystery man” of eighteenth-century Gaelic verse’ [Ronald Black, An Lasair (Edinburgh: Birlinn, 2001), 461]. Of course, both may have been descendants – or, in MacIsaac’s case there may have been a connection through fosterage. The family connection might explain their knowledge of the manuscript Fear o’n Gharbh-thìr, and their shared interest in traditional tales.
Hector MacIsaac is also mentioned in a marginal note written on 16 December 1874 CW380 f.90v, the same day as the birth of the Carmichaels’ third child Iain Macdonald Carmichael.

Hector MacIsaac is one of the most vivid of Carmichael’s informants, his intense and forceful personality making itself felt in all the recordings he made. Carmichael pays the following, albeit not entirely dependable, tribute to the storyteller in the introduction to Carmina Gadelica: The hut of Hector Macisaac, Ceannlangavat, South Uist, stood in a peat-moss. The walls were of ‘riasg’, turf, and the thatch of ‘cuilc’, reeds, to the grief of the occupants, who looked upon the reed as banned, because it was used on Calvary to convey the sponge with the vinegar. The hut was about fifteen feet long, ten feet broad, and five feet high. There was nothing in it that the vilest thief in the lowest slum would condescend to steal. It were strange if the inmates of this turf hut in the peat-morass had been other than ailing. Hector Macisaac and his wife were the only occupants, their daughter being at service trying to prolong existence in her parents. Both had been highly endowed physically, and were still endowed mentally, though now advanced in years. The wife knew many secular runes, sacred hymns, and fairy songs; while the husband had numerous heroic tales, poems, and ballads.I had visited these people before, and in September 1871, Iain F. Campbell of Islay and I went to see them. Hector Macisaac, the unlettered cottar who knew no language but his own, who came into contact with no one but those of his own class, his neighbours of the peat-bog, and who had never been out of his native island, was as polite and well-mannered and courteous as Iain Campbell, the learned barrister, the world-wide traveller, and the honoured guest of every court in Europe. Both were at ease and at home with one another, there being neither servility on the one side nor condescension on the other. The stories and poems which Hector Macisaac went over during our visits to him would have filled several volumes. Mr. Campbell now and then put a leading question which brought out the story-teller’s marvellous memory and extensive knowledge of folklore. [CG i, xx]

Hector MacIsaac died of old age on 11 July 1878, at his home in Ardmore, Iochdar, South Uist. Hector MacIsaac’s wife, Ann MacLellan (c1808–1883) gave Carmichael a series of charm texts on 16 October 1867 CW87/22-28.

chronItem.event: mentioned in a note by Alexander Carmichael
